reviewText:
Very rarely do I ever come across a game that is aout as painful to play as it is so creative and rich I want to play it anyway. Overall the game has an amazing world, very rich lore you could play for months and still learn a little something new, perfect atmosphere and great mechanics. However this game suffers from the horrible curse of being so hard to play its not so much fun but more of a challenge.

Good aspects:
-As I said the world is incredibly well thought out and populated with so many things
-The mechanics while not completely new are very tailored to this game and fit well
-Characters feel real and not: Hello I am the Tutorial quest
-The map and quests/events often change so you wont always get the same results

Now comes the other side of the game the negative. I dont mind a challenging game, FTL is challenging but just fair enough to keep you coming back for more. This game expects you to die and die often. More often than not 2 things will happen. 1. Run out of fuel and then the trouble starts usually leading to the end of the game. 2. the food runs out which leads to the end of the game. This game really had such marvolous potential but the fact of the matter is you only have so much space for fuel and food (not counting cargo if you want to make a profit) and if your a person who likes to explore and investigate a world vs just going from quest to quest you wont get much of a chance here.

Bad aspects:
-you only have so much space for fuel and food so you have to make choices
- it is REALLY hard to make money in this game
-when you die all your progress in the game resets (maps, money, treasure)
-the distance between islands is very long so exploring unknown places means you wont last long in a small boat
-the game promises to be lovecraftian and filled with horrors, but they arnt easy to find and not nearly as exciting or rewarding as you would think
-combat sucks unless you have very exspensive equipment
-unless you have acomplished very hard to do quests, you dont get to keep hardly anything from your last game
-the game punishes curiosity more than it rewards it

So here is my advice, if you want a game that takes hours to play, has tons of content and a facinating world this is a great game to buy. However if you want to have FUN or explore it, download Cheat Engine to solve the money problems. It does make the game more enjoyable.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sunless Sea is an exploration and resource management game, with a VERY heavy focus on the writing and general atmosphere. The game is not fast paced, it is aimed at people who want to enjoy the exploration of it's giant map, the people that want to read for the majority of their time in game.

For this reason, Sunless Sea is inevitably love or hate. If you enjoy reading AND difficult resource management and route planning, you will love this game. These are not always things that go together however, so it is definitely not for everyone.

Personally I love this game. I enjoy the long treks into the sea, I enjoy writing down which items I need, and keeping track of where I can get them. I enjoy running the same trade routes to get the money I need for upgrades and quests. It is an excellent game, with very few flaws.

Outside of the game being very niche, the only other flaws are minor UI bugs; the objectives tab is pretty useless so expect to write things down in order to remember them, many other values are pretty unclear and there is sometimes clipping in item discription when reading rewards/costs of actions.

All in all, this is a great game for the kind of people it was made for, and will not be for everyone. If you're okay with dying to explore, learning from your mistakes, and taking in a vaste new world; I recommend you buy this game. You will easily get 100 hours of gameplay out of this if you learn the basics, and if you love it you will get even more.

reviewText: Fallen London and Sunless Sea, Failbetter's text based RPG and ship-based RPG in turn are superb pieces of work for their own reasons. Sunless Sea mixes tight controls, a delectable setting and delightful storytelling into one darkly humourous package. I bought this game the first day it appeared on Early Access and even then, it showed an unprecedented level of polish. Throughout its development, that's been consistant and it shows in the final product.\n\nBuy it. Lose your mind. Read and sail. You'll be doing a lot of both.

reviewText: This game is more of a novel than a game. And it's a damn good novel. Because it does something that novels tend to be unable to do due to the very detached nature of reading. Rather than have you sympathize with a protagonist, you are the protagonist. That's part of why so many people play games; it's simply more interactive and immersive. What Sunless Sea does somehow goes further than even that level of immersion. It doesn't just show you a world you can play through, it gives you a world to live in. I feel uneasy and lonely and even sick at the things that happen, especially the things I do. This is simply the best storytelling experience I have ever had. No other game even comes close.

reviewText: heres my two cents on the game. First off i love good stories and good lore so on those two things this game rocks. I also love how the game rewards exploration and the more you explore the better off you get. okaay now this might cause some hate but i think the combat fits the game really well. your just one captin versus giant monsters exploring the vastness of a hostile world. that being said maby the starting area monsters should have been a little less punishing. also im a horrible gamer and it took me forever to reach gators mourn so take this review with a pinch or maby a tablespoon of salt.  also even though i only have 10 hours in game time ive reached as far south as iron republic and as far west to the rat/guine pig island.  so i feel i have a good understanding of the game mechanics. also a tip hot keys are really efficent and can save your life in this game like i have 400 plus hours on eu4 and i dont use hotkeys there so im just sayin there a little helpful here so have fun on the unterr zee.

reviewText:
So many wonderful things happen in this game. Got cursed by a sea god, and found my wife and child dead upon returning to port. Jeez, high stakes here. Chased by a living iceberg, fled to a narrow fjord that the iceberg couldn't enter, and spent days chipping away at it with the deck gun until it finally keeled over. Spent dozens of hours on an epic quest to discover my father's bones, long lost at sea, only to discover he wasn't fully human! Fought an ill-considered battle against some behemoth of the deep, which wrecked my boat and killed most of my crew. The journey back to London was a nail-biting epic - fleeing from other mosters at reduced speed, creeping around in the dark, desperately charting course for a temporary haven to buy more fuel and supplies... when I finally made it it felt like a real accomplishment.

The narratives and atmospherics of this game are just amazing. I am lost to sunless sea...

which is not to say it can't be improved! Some of the story lines seem to peter out early, without a satisfying end to what had been a tantalizing opening. Sea combat can feel a bit routine after a while. And the world could be a bit more dynamic, in terms of things changing in reponse to the player's actions. A better interface for making notes and tracking missions would be good - as it stands now, I have to keep a pad of paper next to me to jot things down, remember what's where, and what I was up to last time I played. And a broader selection of useful boats would be nice, together with maybe a warehouse in town.

But these are all minor concerns. This game is already a masterpiece, and will become more so as more stories are added to the already rich mix of captivating strangeness.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Incredibly immersive and fantastically absurd, this is a wonderfully written and diverse piece of interactive literature.

Your life can range from a heroic explorer of the world who serves London and civilization while writing romantic novels about your adventures in your free time.

Or you can be a swashbuckling wealthmonger who who enslaves guinea pigs for fun and manically cackles over the piles of money stained with the blood of whoever.

OR you can become a holy vessel of the divine forces that be and drive a bloody crusade through the world, while making sure to get back to Volcano Island in time to have tea and a lovely chat with Grandma Satan.

Overall goals vary wildly.  The game gives you a selection of vague criteria to end it but the best idea is to set your own personal goals.  Build your own character and instead of min maxing, think to yourself Would my character sell a crewmate and dear friend to cannibals just to churn out a profit?  Absolutely!"

Overall it's an enriching and captivating experience for those who like to read and forge their own story."

reviewText:
It took me a few tries but I finally got into this game and now I'm hooked. It really does take a while to get started and the pace really is slow so I understand that some people might be turned off by it. But I stuck with it and allowed myself to get immeresed in all the little stories you start weaving together once you start exploring more and now I can't stop playing.

I'm also not a fan of Rogue-like games in general but since this is more Rogue-lite I find it more forgiving that other games like FTL. I feel like the rogue-like aspect of the game is just enough to keep the tension up during your long travels but not so hard that it feels frustrating. Plus, as long as you live long enough to have a will, it also ensures that you'll be better equipped when you start a new game.

All in all it's a nice little game that I play if I want something atmospheric and not too intense too play.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
A haiku summing up my feels on Sunless Sea:

Waves upon the bow;
False stars fall from the ceiling;
The Zee claims all things.

-----------

Prior to finding this game on Steam, I've never heard of Sunless Sea, Fallen London, or its creators Failbetter Games. But as someone who really enjoys writing and good storytelling, along with the whole Victorian-era steampunk aesthetic, Sunless Sea quickly became one of my favorite games. At first, the writing might be a little overwhelming to those more accustomed to faster-paced roguelike/survival games, but it's the writing and quests you find yourself immersed in that keep you coming back for more. While the game thrives as an interactive story told over the lifetimes of numerous captains you create and play as (with more chapters and content added post-release regularly for free), it's still decently fun when it comes to combat and exploration. Albeit, your safer bet is on the latter if you intend on making money and surviving early on, but there's nothing wrong with wanting to hunt some of the more dreadful monsters lurking in the deeps.

Be careful though: much like the dastardly Zeebeasties, you'll soon find yourself swallowed up by this game.

See what I did there? Now go try this game.

reviewText: Sunless Sea is a beautiful, haunting game full of secrets and mysteries. It's a hard game; it will take you a while to build up the skills and wealth you need to battle the Lorn-Fluke or complete the Neathbow. But the journeys you take on the way to wealth and fame are as strange and wondrous as the destination, full of shadows and giant spiders and inexplicably-alive statues and, occasionally, cannibalism. Sunless Sea is a difficult and haunting game, but it's a game worth the effort, and a story worth being haunted by.

reviewText:
Holy f**k, this game's narrative is really good! If you like the whole H.P. Lovecraft, Terry Pratchett and Neil Gaiman style of writing, you WILL LOVE this game.

It's a mix of Lovecraft with Pratchett and some steampunk visuals with the feel of Gaiman's Neverwhere London. Like there's a whole civilization on a dimension just below our own.

I cannot recommend this game enough, if you like this kind of lore.

reviewText:
I've honestly lost count of how many times I've ran out of fuel, launched lifeboats and died...
...Not even a kilometer away from London's harbor.

It's a fun game, but random map generation will mean you set off to where you THINK an island is, only to realize too late that it's nowhere close and you don't have enough money or fuel to get back.
Then you'll die, curse yourself for being an idiot and start up a new game.

And do it all again.

EDIT:
After getting a bit more time into this, I'm pretty taken with it. It's a lot of fun, and the world design is beautiful. Almost every island island I've visited has a story to explore and something to do, and there' something strangely calming about zailing the darkenned waters of the zee.

reviewText:
This is a good game, but it is a broken game.

It is a exploration game that consists of captaining a ship through the Lovecraftian sea beside Fallen London.  The synopsis of the game is very accurate.  It's a bit heavy on resource management and there is quite a bit of pointless grinding, but it's really fun.  Exploring the sea is challenging, there are always these new shocks and surprises and the game keeps you on your toes.

But it's a broken game.  It's broken in that the death of your character can occur in random encounters.  You can build up a captain with 30 hours of sailing in between ports, have a nice powerful ship, and then- bam- random street encounter, he's dead, and all that progress is lost.  There's no way to judge the lethality of encounters, especially encounters in ports, before making a decision.  Hence, death and the loss of the character has this whimsical aspect to it.  It's like getting insta-killed by a monster you can't see.  So, a broken game.  I think the designers wanted something with the lethality of Dark Souls
date: maybe.  Who knows?  They screwed up.\n\nTo play the game successfully, like with Dark Souls
recommended: requires manipulating the game mechanics themselves.  Specifically, figuring out when the game auto-saves and using that to your advantage.  If you die at sea, alt-f4 the game, closing it, opening it again, and then reload the last autosave.\n\nIt's cheesy.  It's cheap.  It's borderline cheating, but that's how to fix the design flaws.  Once that's done, it's really fun.  So, a B+ game.  Good, but flawed.  With fixable flaws.

reviewText: This game was a surprise to me and generally quite a lot of fun on my first couple of runs. The game plays out fairly casually and has a nice ambience to it. This game has a major issue however, as I am sure many other reviewers have mentioned. It is far too slow. Now I imagine the game was made slow deliberately to add to the atmosphere, but after playing a couple playthroughs this becomes painful. This game NEEDS A SPEED UP BUTTON. An optional X2 or X5 option would be great to cut down on pointless travel time. Once you've played through the map and discovered what this game has to offer, plodding around for 5-10 minutes to get to a destination is utterly pointless and makes me hate this game. If this game had a speedup button I would probably give it an 8/10 but it's become so frustrating that I cannot recommend it until they add one.

reviewText:
Sunless Sea is a game about exploring a vast subterranean sea. It offers permadeath and is not a roguelike. You start by gathering some supplies for a ship and then sail into the black unknown, map uncharted. The map’s cut into zones that points of interest (PoIs) can randomly spawn in, with the exception of the border PoIs being static. In every playthrough, all PoIs will be available, and thereby nearly all stories that the game has to offer. The stories are both the game’s strongest and weakest points.

Positives

Stripped entirely of story, the game would be boring: bring something here, revisit this place when, slowly (very) upgrade your ship. Standard fare. It’s the story that you come and stay for, and it kept me playing far longer than I expected to. The writing is almost always of Excellent quality. The story is fairly plausible within Fallen London’s most-anything-can-happen internal logic. I had no trouble being immersed in the atmosphere.

The graphics are pretty and the character/quality pictures are drawn well. I’ll never forget a certain moment in my first fight against a certain zee (sea) creature.

The combat is good. I feel like it could be just a little more, but it doesn’t need to be more. I personally enjoyed hunting zee beasts.

It feels like a roguelike in the regard that a minor miscalculation can ruin your voyage quickly. I remember a long procession of misery that all stemmed from my inclination to fight a bound-shark when I had low fuel, leaving me at the mercy of the gods, who happened to think sending me to a far-away DEATH ISLAND was a great means of salvation. I got so many Steam “achievements” for that one and I barely made it out alive. Was a good time!

Criticism

The islands are insular and only very rarely (do they even?) will the stories overlap between PoIs. “I need Scintillack, which you can get at this place.” does not count as two islands interacting with each other. In a way this is good because each island is manageable, but it certainly isn’t plausible and a more dynamic Sunless Sea would have been appreciated. For example, in the case of the Isle of Cats, I took a shipment from a Cat-Woman to London. I then screwed her over by selling it for double. I then returned, beat her up, and made a similar deal with a tiger who I proceeded to do the same thing to, but I never returned. That was early on and I didn’t heard a peep of it for the rest of the game.

The stories are great -- the first time. On the second playthrough, you can make different choices, but it’s still the same base story you’re playing. This diminishes replay value when the game’s drawing feature is how great the stories are. The saving grace is that I still had a few PoIs to really dig into, and the reality is the stories will less fresh when I play again in two years.

Upgrading your house and to a smaller extent, your boat, are hardly upgrades. You essentially upgrade your house to pay more to sleep in it. With boats, they get heavier and thereby slower, with the first major upgrade only offering a Forward slot for all that trouble. It comes with higher crew requirements and it’s slower, so you’re paying more than just the 3,000 echoes after the fact. Where boats should expand the gameplay or offer an alternative, you really only have access to a merchant-vessel for making (poorly defensible) big trips carrying loads of cargo, but it’s still ponderous and you can only have one ship at a time.

I broke out my mobile phone a little too often during long, boring commutes from island to island. Something should be done when the player hasn’t touched the keyboard for 15+ seconds. Only when I bought the +2,500 engine power engine did it really feel like I was blazing around -- then I upgraded the ship and it got a bit slower, buzzkill. There’s some method of getting a great engine and then going at Full Power, but I never tried it and it’d be noisy as Hell anyway.

Finally, the Supremacy mechanic could be much more fun than it really is. I made London Supreme, so where are our navy boats floating around the zee? Why did the Khan seem to give absolutely no care about it?

OVERALL

Buy the game! It’s really fun! Highly recommended. Support developers who write words. They/we’re the future of the richest gaming experiences.

reviewText:
For the first few hours of this game, unless you consult a guide, you will have no idea what you're doing. And that's okay. You will lose your first captain fairly quickly. But when a captain dies, the next one can inherit certain aspects of their life, ranging from weapons to money to heirlooms. Soon you'll have some notion of what's going on.

From an artistic standpoint, Sunless Sea is appealing. You will encounter a variety of islands and environments, discovering lore along the way, all set to a fitting soundtrack.

From a gameplay perspective, there are things that can be improved. You will spend most of your time sailing from island to island, trading, documenting, and trying not to be killed by zee monsters. Fuel and supplies are a near constant worry, because if either runs out while you're at zee, your ship is practically gone. Spending time at zee will also increase Terror, another important stat. It will take some time before you are even able to purchase a bigger ship; unless you know what you're doing, gold is scarce.

There is hope, though. You can choose to acquire a merchant ship, which has significant cargo space for efficient trading. Or you can choose the heavier battle ships to hunt monsters.

There's no doubt that you will die at least once before you're able to hold your own against the dark zee. But if you're persistant enough (or foolish enough), you can probably find some way to not lose your mind.

Probably.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Welcome to the Unterzee, captain.
Here, amongst the people of Fallen London, you will sail out into the vast unknown, making your way. You will have goals and ambitions- they may not be satisfied. You may not survive. You may eat your crew. One simply never knows, and that is life on the Unterzee.
My advice, from one captain to another- don't fight the zee-beasts. It is unlikely to end well. Also don't fuss too much with upgrading your ship- you'll want most of the echoes you save to go towards fuel and supplies, which are the life blood of any running ship.
Of note- the Unterzee is a big place, and your ship is slow. It will take time to go where you would like to, and often more time when going somewhere you'd rather not like to. But there is so much to see here, so many stories to hear, that the journey will always be worth it.
So go on, explore, and see the wonders and cultures to be found on the myriad shores of the Unterzee. Just keep a wary eye open- life is never simple here, and so often dangers lurk unseen in the darkness.
Good luck.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I am really enjoying the feel of this game.  The graphics and the soundtraxk really set the mood well and the gameplay has been compelling so far.

This sat in my wishlist for many months as it looked and sounded great and I finally jumped in recently when it was on sale.  I would highly recommend anyone grabbing it on sale and for those that like the sound of it they probably won't be disappointed.

Each time you die you can leave a legacy for your next captain and after 7 hours in I am on my 3rd captain and working further into the game each time.  It can be hard and it can be slow paced but overall a rich and enjoyable experience so far.

reviewText:
A story as thick as the fog of the Wolfstack docks.
I really really have to recommend playing this without looking up spoilers; it is a game that only works with your sense of wonder intact, your hunger to explore unstatisfied and your paranoia that something horrible is coming for you with every decision at full force.

Best game I've played all year. Utterly brilliant storytelling and setting. And totally not for everyone.

If you enjoy games that focus more on story than on gameplay, more on setting than on graphics and more on immersion than convenience, this is absolutely the game for you. But I can absolutely see how people might hate this game - it's slow, you'll spend probably more than half the game 'just reading text' and it is not easy to figure out how things work, you more or less have to make your own mistakes.

As said, best game I've played all year... And one of the best settings I've ever encountered. Also, if you want more of fallen london and the dark, wide zee, I'd recommend you check out FBG's browser game 'Fallen London'.

reviewText:
Hello, delicious readers!
If you've played Fallen London, then you HAVE to play Sunless Sea. You have too. No exceptions. If you haven't played Fallen London, you still HAVE to play Sunless Sea.
A little slow to start but if you appreciate thoughful and creative story with a LOT of dry and dark humor, you won't be able to stop playing this.
Very rewarding storylets and exploration functions, great visuals and soundtrack and I could just go on and on but I don't want to ruin anything for you guys.

Now, just because this is basically 2D and it's not first person/jumpscare-arific, doesn't mean it isn't scary. There are plenty of goosebumpy and grind-your-teeth moments throughout the whole game.

If you're a writer (leisure or professional), this is a great tool to use to develop your grammar bank and pacing habits.
Overall, 11/10, Failbetter Games. I tip my sharkskin hat in your general direction.

reviewText:
Play this game only if you fulfill all of the following:

- you liked Mieville's 'Perdido Street Station'
- you are HPL fanatic
- you are all into stories and atmosphere in the games/books/movies
- you have a vivid imagination
- you have 100 hours free (or supposedly 200 if you go on the permadeath route)
- you don't mind occassional rage quits or even rage uninstalls
- you have a strategic mind
- you don't mind sitting by the game with pen and paper writing all the important stuff down (as it was in the old days)
- you are not a vegetarian
- you have at least some psychopathical traits
- you are proficient in English (not just fluent, proficient)

If you don't fulfill all of the above, you will be heavily frustrated.

I failed with the 100hours criterion. Having played 7, I've seen less than 1/4 locations from the trailers on this page but I just can't afford to put so much time into one game. Even if it's as perfect as Sunless Sea.

reviewText:
Sail an acrid, strange zee deep beneath the earth, lapping the shores of Hell.

This game is like, all words. There's ship bits but they're not the fun part. (They're not boring either, though!)

This game is DRIPPING (literally sometimes!) with atmosphere, from the lonely, quiet voyages set to mournful, empty sea shanties to the actual meat of the game, the little mini-text-adventures on different island.

The characters are handled in a really vague, distant way that works for the game's emphasis on mystery and it's really conducive to roleplaying individual captains as different.

There's permadeath (which you CAN turn off) also, which combined with the islands rearranging slightly when you die makes every run feel really fresh.

If you play Fallen London, get this game. If you don't and like the idea story-based cosmic-horror-sea-trading you should get this, because it does this VERY WELL.

reviewText:
Different type of game than anything I have played.

Its fun. But a little time consuming when travelling from place to place. Would be good if you could speed up time to lower wasted game time.

Hope there are some good ship upgrades that lower travel time. Have not had a chance to get any yet.

I have died 4 times. Onto my 5th capt.

Don't read any guides, this game is about discovery. Reading walkthroughs will just spoil the game for you. Unless you are really stuck.

I have some nit picks about not being able to write your own journey notes. Like in instances where some ports require some stuff. By the time you are back in London you have forgotten what you need to take.

Combat isn't the games strong suit. Can be frustrating at times, but when you start to get the hang of it, it becomes less of a chore.

Worth it to buy. You will get at least 80 hours out of this game, if you want to explore it fully.

reviewText:
Yet another Kickstarter success,  this game is just awesomely bizarre from a lot of angles:

1).  The world is a alternate universe ancient London and nearby areas that fell from above ground to a great giant, underground sea

2). That world, the Unterzee, and Fallen London, is inspired by Cthulthu mythos stuff, and is in a Mythos-esque universe

3).   The game is a naval adventure that puts you at the helm of an ancient and hoary steamboat.

4).  You fight against other creatures in the Unterzee by maneuvering around and firing at them.  With weapons.

5).  You collect a variety of allies and NPCs for various roles on your boat, and some of them are....well to say seedy would be fluffing them up a bit.

6).  You choose a destiny at the beginning of the game and then try to fulfill it.

7).  In traditional RPG style gaming, you gain stuff, money, and crew.

8).  You choose the game you want to play.  There are a few runs you can do to make some money running cargo from one place to another.  But fuel, repairs, and food for your ship and crew can be pretty pricey.

9).  The game is pretty hard on you, and has perma-death normally enabled.   (You can turn it off).  There have been times I have done a cargo run, purchased a bunch of stuff, finished a quest and gotten my quest reward, and then only to have lost money after refitting and repairing my ship

10).  This game takes its time.  It's not some quick and fast game.  You move and fight with enough time to get things working and to prevent issues.



That's a pretty odd set of stuff for the game.  And it's a fun game.  The flavor for this game is just outstanding.  Sunless Sea has some of the best writing of any game I've ever played period.


And Flavor?  It's oozing with it from every single tentacle.  From the squid like humanoids to various eldritch additions to your crew, and yourself, it's good.  In various ports you have people, quests, exploring, allies, enemies, and more.  From stores to upgrade your ship or to purchase new ones, to buying and picking up some stuff for your crew and officers, there's a lot to do.  Make sure to keep your terror levels as low as possible too, by the by...


Get ready for a creepy, fun, slow-paced, game that really pushes Roguelike games to the next level in my mind.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sunless Sea is great, but you have to be literate to enjoy it. If you don't want to read, don't play this game. The story is hard to follow as it doesn't spoon feed you everything, but exploration is very rewarding. However, you end up spending more money on fuel and supplies than you actually get from questing. It plays out as a choose your own adventure. I love the characters and the universe in which the game is set.

This game is a time sink. You will be grinding and it is very rough on hard mode. This is not for the feint of heart.

Is it worth nearly $20? I'd say catch it on sale, but that's just me.

reviewText:
basically a naval verion of Darkest Dungeon set in a Victorian-era theme, with a lil Rogue Legacy thrown in for seasoning, similar price as well

personally im super thrifty, so id like to see it cheaper than $10, but regardless, its a decent game, even though IMHO there are a ton of other equally great games around the 10-15$ pricepoint albeit different genres, but i like all kinds [Valdis Story, Dust: an Elysian Tail, Underrail, etc]

all in all, i found it fun/interesting, even though it is a very slow/boring game at times, but this is all part of the intended design asthetic [this is why ppl saying the game needs a fast-travel option r both wrong and ignorant]

BUT... as much as i liked the game and its atmosphere and a lot of its rich flavor, it consistently leaves me wanting/disappointed, not to mention that its still got plenty of bugs {which is sad, becuz from what i understand the dev team is busy working on a DLC expansion... =[, always sad to see the pursuit of more $$$ when the original turd isnt even fully polished yet [not completely fair as the game is not a 'turd']}

many ppl have praised the clever writing and FWIW, its good anachronistic victorian lovecraft ; but at the same time, its the good stuff about the game that makes you question the 'meh' stuff even more

sadly many interesting and useful features were lost along the way from alpha to release [used to have a neat ship icon in the upper left that showed hold space], there was going to be a more robust ship customization suite, and a few others

personally i think that there should still be some kind of hybrid from the turn-based txt combat interactions and the real-time, FWIW i dont dislike the real-time, but having some story/lore/flavor pop-up more than just after the fact occasionally would be good [for example, not all pirates could be initially aggressive, they could try to intimidate or merely 'ask' politely for yer ship/crew/hold/etc and then only atk if u refuse or fail a stats check]

also why is there so little interaction with light/buoy ships? wouldnt it make sense that those ships and their crew would be eager to trade for supplies or crew occasionally?

others have said the same, but it really feels like they missed some huge opportunity by not having more complexity/depth/story to the 4-5 nearest locations to FL

why is there no option to remove crew at port? do ppl rly never want to leave this ship? doubtful, considering its voyages [i like the inherent meta-strat around the min-max of crew, personally i think that more crew beyond 50% should just continue to improve firing-calc/dmg/spd/etc, but potentially make crew a bit more expensive to compensate, there is already the 'downside' of more crew eating more supplies]

why is there no interaction with other non-violent npc vessels? surely these lonely frigates and their crews/captains have stories to tell/trade ;  why is there no interaction between different zee monsters? are they all in a friendly cabal? why is there no interaction between zee beast and other vessels? nothing like having a jelly and a pirate tag-teaming and worldstar'n yer ship ; also wouldnt it be neat to be able to help another frigate being attacked by zee beasts or pirates? and of course u would be choosing how to 'help'

the romance at home back in london is also very shallow compared to the officers on the ship, this seems like a bit of an oversight?

almost every time i clicked on a hostile vessel i was stuck in 'combat' mode and was unable to get out of combat until i made port, a small bug, but an obvious one, also the game routinely got stuck during the transition from shadowy past when u pic a name/face

although i understand this now, it is not immediately intuitive that some shops show things that can only be sold there, but never bought, this could potentially be made clearer

so much interesting gear items in the game just dont have enough going for them, like the aft concealed compartment, its sad that these neat lil things just dont serve much purpose in the grand scheme =/

reviewText: This is a game by people who love to tell interesting stories in an interesting setting, and they do a great job of that. They originally did this in a web game called Echo Bazaar" (later renamed "Fallen London")
date: which had a wonderful setting and stories but was crippled by an expensive time currency.\n\nIn Sunless Sea they've ported this setting and storytelling to a "pay once" game
recommended: but unfortunately they've replaced the time currency with some equally problematic and distracting mechanics. Whereas Fallen London's storytelling was undermined by having to wait (or pay way too much) for the time currency
hoursPlayed: Sunless Sea's storytelling is undermined by spending even more time slogging back and forth across empty oceans at a glacial pace
voteText: desperately trying to scrape together enough money from a broken trade system that you can afford the next expensive thing you need to advance the story. In 90% of cases
helpfulPercent: that "expensive thing you need to advance the story" is just enough basic supplies and fuel to reach the next plot checkpoint.\n\nSometimes you fight bad guys in a brainless combat system that involves going toe-to-toe with them until one of you dies
votesHelpful: but the rewards for combat are typically much lower than the unavoidable repairs for the combat will cost you.\n\nSo what could be done to fix it? The core problem is pacing

reviewText:
TLDR: It's difficult. It's terrifying on an imaginary level. It's full of curiosities and stories!!!

I don't quite know how to describe this game. It is challenging and interesting in a curious way. Fallen London seems to be this under-earth sea civilization and you're simply living your life trying to make a go of thing.

The atmosphere in this game is what captures my imagination and my mind is filled with these vibrant scenes and imagery of what's being described in the game.

You're going to die. You have to take risks. It's terrifying. I love it.

reviewText:
Holy f**k, this game's narrative is really good! If you like the whole H.P. Lovecraft, Terry Pratchett and Neil Gaiman style of writing, you WILL LOVE this game.

It's a mix of Lovecraft with Pratchett and some steampunk visuals with the feel of Gaiman's Neverwhere London. Like there's a whole civilization on a dimension just below our own.

I cannot recommend this game enough, if you like this kind of lore.

reviewText:
I've honestly lost count of how many times I've ran out of fuel, launched lifeboats and died...
...Not even a kilometer away from London's harbor.

It's a fun game, but random map generation will mean you set off to where you THINK an island is, only to realize too late that it's nowhere close and you don't have enough money or fuel to get back.
Then you'll die, curse yourself for being an idiot and start up a new game.

And do it all again.

EDIT:
After getting a bit more time into this, I'm pretty taken with it. It's a lot of fun, and the world design is beautiful. Almost every island island I've visited has a story to explore and something to do, and there' something strangely calming about zailing the darkenned waters of the zee.

reviewText:
Sunless Sea doesn't initially seem to offer much. Until it does. The game is set in across an underground ocean, where current and tides shift the islands and landmasses around every once in a while. You're the captain of ship amongst many others, in a world of Lovecraftian piracy where smuggled sunlight and spirit-infused honey are contraband goods.

It's not a game for the wilfully illiterate. If you are annoyed by reading paragraphs upon paragraphs of texts on the sidebars, Sunless Sea probably isn't for you. After all, the game derived from a browser-based game called Fallen Londoni consisting of large swathes of text to go through.

As you create your character, you also designate your aspiration, which may be retiring rich or perhaps making a great discovery. You're then set with a rickety ship at the Wolfstack Docks in Fallen London. Through trading, piracy and other quests, you're going to make money, improve your ship and recruit a crew.

Sunless Sea mainly features a bird's eye view of Unterzee, the abovementioned underground ocean. You navigate these waters and find your way around by deploying a Zeebat, which scans a large circle around your ship, allowing you to explore the map. For what is essentially an animated map, Sunless Sea looks spectacular. The artworks in some of the islands are simply things of sheer beauty to look. Many islands feature some sort of trading post, which you should manipulate, so to speak, and buy cheap to sell dear. When you learn how to manage your fuel and supplies, and remember the price rates in varipus ports, making decent amounts of money becomes manageable.

During your voyages, you're accompanied by a crew. These are divided into named" characters and anonymous crew. Anonymous crew consists of the "brute" force of your ship and they determine the efficiency of your speed and maneuverability. In other words
recommended: the slower you'll sail and turn. Then
hoursPlayed: there are the named NPCs

helpfulPercent: Chef and so on. These characters come with certain benefits and improvements to your ship
votesHelpful: not to mention their specific quests and backstories. These quests sometimes lead to further improvement of their traits
votesTotal: which makes them worth following through.\n\nWhile out there in the Unterzee
votesFunny: your Insanity meter will crawl up. Darkness is a major factor in this - if you stray from the buoys dispersed across the Unterzee
commentsCount: the darkness will slowly madden you and your crew. This leads to nightmares

column18: you may end with a mutinee. Of course
column19: these lamp-mounted buoys are not particularly linear in their positions - straight sailing from one to the other will deplete your fuel unduly
column20: while ignoring them altogether will cause undue Insanity. This is one of many micro-management deals in the game.\n\nThe soundtrack of the game is often pleasant and sometimes particularly beautiful. As it doesn't loop often
column21: the sudden introduction of the background music adds to the eerieness and tension
column22: whereas returning to the Wolfstack Docks will almost always be matched with one of the more warmer tracks to emphasise that homecoming feeling.\n\nSunless Sea nevertheless skirts around the niche category. Its long texts
column23: necessary for the its intricate stories
column24: do not speak to all players
column25: neither does the micromanagement of scarce maritime resources promise joy to everybody. Yet
column26: for those who do enjoy such features
column27: as well as those who have liking of Lovecraftian themes
column28: Sunless Sea is a satisfactory title."

reviewText: This game takes forever to really get going but that desperate struggle just to get your footing makes the disturbing, eldritch setting all that much more unsettling. The exploration is top notch and the writing is phenomenal. You gleam tiny snippets of information at a time and soon realize the world and its history is enormous and more surreal than you could ever imagine. It's a lot of reading, but the writing is worth it. I'm so hooked on this universe that I've gotten into the browser game Fallen London too, and it's very interesting to explore the Neath at different angles at once.

reviewText:
Sunless Sea is such an interesting concept but is hampered by some really poor decisions. There's a reason I call it Funless Sea.

The good part is that the developers have crafted a weird, wonderful world populated with interesting stories and artwork. The mood is great. The world is interesting. The stories are kind of cool and occasionally not just a little messed up in the head. The world is the same close to your base but in every game it gets more and more randomized the further you get. That's a wonderful gameplay idea and I give serious props to the devs for creating such a great universe.

Unfortunately, they didn't know what to do with it. People will talk about the decent writing, the dark mood, the truly unique world that was created when they praise this game. What they don't talk about is the gameplay and that's where this falls flat. There is no direction and there are really no aims in this game. You get in a ship and go...wherever. It doesn't really seem to matter. You'll find a rare workable trade route and do nothing but grind it as long as you can because money is hard to come by. You'll visit the same ports over and over getting nothing but port reports for a few echos (dollars) at a time when it takes tens of thousands to get a new ship. The pace of the ship is ponderous (and that's being kind). So underneath this interesting world the game devolves into a slow, dull grind. It's really a shame because even mediocre gameplay mechanics could have gone a long way here.

Yes, the pace is supposed to reflect the tension of your slowly deteriorating crew. To some respect it does that. But more often than not my head just wants to hit the keyboard from playing this. My time is more valauble than that. Most of the people I've talked to that have enjoyed" the game used cheats to boost their gold to get somewhere in this bore-fest. I love good exploration games
date: but this feels aimless and pointless to me.\n\nNot that I haven't give it a chance. I tried buying it and then returned it under the Steam policy. I tried again when they had a free weekend and really tried to like this game. But I just can't find the fun in it. Funless Sea - such a great world marred by such boring gameplay."

reviewText:
The writing in this game is amazing. The variety in the stories spread across the islands is captivating. Playing Sunless Sea is not dissimilar to getting hooked on a really good book, with the addition of atmospheric music that matches the mood and feel of the game perfectly. Add to this the agonising decision making and the continuous, tempting gambles the game seduces you into (and probably requires) to make progress, and you begin to understand the call of Zee.

Is it a bit grinding? In all honesty, yes, it takes a while to re-reach the same place in the/a story after the death of a Captain. That said, the game would lose a lot of the trepidation that makes it so enthralling if the permadeath had no consequences.

On a more personal note I am a HUGE fan of the Victorian Gothic styling of the game universe. I don't think this game could have worked as well in any other setting.

Once again, the writing is brilliant. It captures the essence of weird horror perfectly. It makes the game unique, eerie and powerful. It drew me in more than pretty much any other game ever has. Go play it.

date: which had a wonderful setting and stories but was crippled by an expensive time currency.\n\nIn Sunless Sea they've ported this setting and storytelling to a "pay once" game
recommended: but unfortunately they've replaced the time currency with some equally problematic and distracting mechanics. Whereas Fallen London's storytelling was undermined by having to wait (or pay way too much) for the time currency
hoursPlayed: Sunless Sea's storytelling is undermined by spending even more time slogging back and forth across empty oceans at a glacial pace
voteText: desperately trying to scrape together enough money from a broken trade system that you can afford the next expensive thing you need to advance the story. In 90% of cases
helpfulPercent: that "expensive thing you need to advance the story" is just enough basic supplies and fuel to reach the next plot checkpoint.\n\nSometimes you fight bad guys in a brainless combat system that involves going toe-to-toe with them until one of you dies
votesHelpful: but the rewards for combat are typically much lower than the unavoidable repairs for the combat will cost you.\n\nSo what could be done to fix it? The core problem is pacing
votesTotal: and there are two things that could be done to improve this: fast travel
votesFunny: and the economy.\n\nIf I had the option of "Fast travelling from Port A to Port B is a chancy use of your whatever quality"
commentsCount: instead of spending a half hour slogging across an empty ocean I'd slogged across a hundred times before
column16: that would be a big improvement.\n\nI would also suggest fixing the economy so that the player isn't spending the majority of his time trying not to go bankrupt
column17: and could spend more time focusing on the stories.\n\nIf your game's primary goal is storytelling
column18: but there's so much slog between story snippets that your players forget the stories
column19: and if they see the same text so often that they stop reading
column20: then you're not doing yourself any favors.\n\nThis game is very highly-rated in general
column21: so obviously these aspects don't bother other players as much as they bother me
column22: but I think these additions could give the game broader appeal
column23: and also improve the game for those who already love it."

reviewText:
This game was somewhat interesting but needs some serious work. I dont see it listed as early access but it obviously is. I have run into a lot of issues which effect the ability to even play the game.

At the start you choose your characters past but you can opt to skip this and do it at a later point. I choose to do it later one time and when it asked me to choose a name and a portait it would never lock in the choice so i had to close the game and reopen, at which point i saved some of the choices i made but ignored the name and portrait. I have found a lot of issues like this with menu stuff just not resetting.

If you get into combat with 2 things at once you can only kill the first one then the option to even fire the gun gets locked out  and theres no way to reset it ruining combat. this could easily be fixed by allowing us to enter and exit combat mode at will instead of being locked in combat when a foe is in range.

game pace is too slow, similar to zelda: the wind waker there is a ton of ocean and not much land so the travel times between them is super long. Though I didnt mind it as much in wind waker that game didnt have the fuel and food limitations.

There are 2 resources in the game fuel and supplies. Supplies can be used to repair the ship problem with this is that the supplies are also your food so you are wasting food by duct taping it to your ship as a repair? how the hell do you repair a ship with food?

combat is really lame, an option to fish would be nice. I find that when I am low on supplies theres no crabs around for me to kill for food or i run into 2 of them which means i can kill one then have to absorb damage from the other while trying to get out of combat to fix the game glitches.

I have died 4 times and still have no idea how to pass on things I have gained from the game

despite being a mouse and keyboard game the mouse is only used for clicking icons and text at ports. I dont see why something like holding down left or right click and moving the mouse couldnt let you steer the ship. you move with wasd or arrow keys. not a huge issue but im just used to having mutiple control methods in my games. I also find myself hitting esc to try and exit on of game prompts but all this does is open the game menu.

reviewText:
On paper, this game is a 10/10 for me. As a fan of weird fiction, story rich game, exploration, rogue-likes, everything advertised looked golden. So when the Free Weekend came around, I jumped at the chance to give it a go and in a way I wish I hadn't. If I had bought this game instead of demoing it, I would have been dissappointed but would have persevered but as it stands now the weekend is over, I am glad I don't feel compelled to continue just to get my money's worth.

Having played Fallen London, I knew the quality of the writing was going to be impressive but although interesting, almost everything is inconsequential. For a story-driven game, there is very little choice in terms of dialog options and with the permadeath mechanic, you have to read exactly the same lines very playthrough.

All of that would have been fine however if it wasn't for the excruciatingly slow movement of your ship and the terrible UI, which makes following objectives or trying to anticipate what resources are going to inexplicably deplete from a dialog option really frustrating.

In fact, these were all the same frustrations I had with Fallen London, so maybe it's not for me after all.

reviewText: This game seems unfinished, or unpolished, or both. It seems to have gone through some redesign cycles and the gameplay still isn't quite there. The story finds ways to surprise you with deleveling somehow based on conversation" choices that you can make on land... It seems the economy is locked in
date: which makes it nearly impossible to participate in early on once your hold is full of "quest items
recommended:
and not able to sustain you as you travel, without expensive new ships. The available ship designs don't really seem like they were thought through - a result of clear winners and clear losers and the time it takes to save up for these items. This applies to weapons as well and the item economy. The game seems to throw a full page of officers out at you and then mysteriously stop, some leaving without warning during other parts of the story. You have combat/utility and shore/utility options if you remember to change the officers before you take actions.

On the other hand the story itself and the actions you must take to survive enable you to do just that, but this is not a shipping/market/ports game. There is some combat, and you can grind on monsters to supply yourself as you travel, but combat is mostly by convenience, as searching it out will lead to the loss of your resources creating cost to outweigh your savings very quickly.  The simple and few combat mechanics lack excitement and don't seem to evolve. It is definitely frustrating to have to start over from the beginning after you sink well into the game - apparently I completely missed how to engage the inheritance portion of the story in my 12 hours, which allows you to leave more stuff to your heir when you restart.

The UI's small fonts/reading pages and lack of voice narration ultimately adding to my unwillingness to recommend or buy this game after the free weekend. A game I need to have a film or music on to play, as the in game entertainment is intermittent. This is like a book that I need my granny glasses to read unfortunately, as the hours melt away and I'm still wondering how I'm supposed to make money with all these stores and commodities. Maybe they're meant to be used later on as expense reduction...

If you're not here for the fantastic WRITING and the strange(ambitious?) multi-tasking survival/resource/grind dynamic and haunting emptiness... pass.

reviewText:
I'm a little disappointed in this game. I DO enjoy it. However, I was lead to believe certain things about this game from the trailer and reviews that have turned out to be very different in reality.

1. It's a difficult game, and you will die. A lot.
I have yet to die once. Every single death-inducing element - terror, fuel, supplies - is easy enough to manage, even when exploring aggressively. Enemy units can be seen far enough away that it's generally simple to avoid engaging them in battle. I see no need to lose my Invictus charm, because there's no need to bother saving.

2. It's a survival horror game.
I guess this really kind of ties into my first point. There is no horror, and very little survival element (limited to resource management). At absolutely no point have I encountered suspense, because this factor does not exist. There is zero chance that you're going to encounter something entirely unexpected, and so the player has no fear of this happening.

Everything else I'm fine with. I learned from reading others' reviews that the game is slow paced, that earning money to advance is either difficult, or not intuitive. That it becomes tedious to play. That it's very well written, and has excellent story-driven plots. All this I found to be true, and for what the game is, I still enjoy it. Had it been advertised as such, I would recommend it.

However, some fairly important claims are made by the developers, claims that they simply do not deliver on.

I'm also disappointed that the game does not display snippets of text on the screen during events like it does in the trailer, because that would lend an extended air of significance and flair to the written element of the game, which in my opinion, is it's strongest point. However, this did not affect my review.

reviewText:
A slow, stylistic and occassionally thought-provoking title ultimately bogged down by impenetrable lore.

Gameplay is simple and approachable, requiring very little direct interaction.  The pacing of the game is slow, and it is a grueling challenge to advance, especially as you start to run out of completable quests.  Some of the fun comes when having to make hard decisions to progress, and in these moments, the gameplay will briefly flicker with excitement before returning to its routine dullness.  Admittingly, the game hinges more on its story elements than gameplay, so to that effect, the gameplay is enough to service the story.

The style of the game is excellent for an indie title.  Many of the places hidden in the zee are diverse and appropriately Lovecraftian for those seeking that atmosphere.  Music and sound effects help to reinforce the sensation of being adrift in a hostile and alien world.

The story, however, is the issue I have with this title.  While the game is well written in regards to having an artistic style, the background and lore of this game do not convey well through the writing.  I often found myself reading paragraph after paragraph of dialogue based around histories, cultures and phenomenons I knew nothing about and for which there is little lore in game to explain.  I imagine that's the appeal of the game; the thrill of being thrust head first into an alien world that has little regard for your understanding or lack thereof.  However, without comprehension, there can be no investment, and I eventually found myself skimming the text of the game to get the gist of what's going on.  In a game all about text driven story, this is disasterous.

Not to say it's all painfully obscure.  There are genuine moments in the writing that get you feeling excited for what's about to come, typically nestled within the more grounded moments of the game.  There just are not enough to hold my interest past a free weekend playthrough.

For those people already immersed in the lore of Fallen London, this title is a must buy, and will likely appeal to players inclined towards Cthulian games.  For those not willing to take the time to learn and understand this world outside the game, I would recommend other titles.  Planescape Torment, the Witcher franchise and Pillars of Eternity, for instance, do a better job of plunging the player into an alien world while fostering investment.  For those attracted to the Lovecraft style, unforgiving decision driven gameplay and the low price point, Darkest Dungeon is an outstanding substitution.

reviewText:
Sunless Sea is not for me. Seriously, I can't stand this game.

Even the positive reviews admit that the gameplay is lacking. Exploration/movement is glacially slow. Combat is uninteresting and unrewarding. There's virtually no sense of progression even after hours of gameplay. So where's the hook? I don't know. I never found it.

You really have to get into the atmosphere and writing to keep playing this boring mess, but I found neither could make up for the tedious and repetitious gameplay. The game mechanics that make up 90% of the game are so universally dull that I'm truly shocked at how well this game is regarded. The developers are highly creative, but they haven't the slightest clue on how to design a game that's actually fun to play. The game simply lacks pace, unless you consider super-slo-mo to be an appropriate pace for a game.

As a huge fan of FTL and Don't Starve, I fully expected to love Sunless Sea, especially with its emphasis on exploration. What I didn't figure is that the exploration would be so colossally dull. It's possible that Sunless Sea could've been a very good choose your own adventure" game in the style of 80 Days
recommended: I struggle to think of a game in recent memory that I enjoyed less than Sunless Sea."

reviewText:
I don't really want to give Sunless Sea a negative review, but I feel that it has more negative aspects than positive ones.

Pros:
+Excellent writing. Every story I read draws me into their world and I feel like I'm there with the captain.
+Risk/reward gambling. You can go farther out into the Unterzee for more profits/adventure, but the risk of something going wrong and dying horribly also increases with your distance from London.
+Everything has lore, and lots of it. If you're not a fan of reading a lot, this game isn't for you.
+Randomization of events keeps the game interesting as you make your rounds collecting port reports.

Cons:
-Permadeath. With a game this lore heavy, permadeath should not be a thing. You can avoid permadeath by making manual saves, but you'll still lose lots of time every time you die and read/skip the same things over again.
-The game actively punishes you for going faster. You'll have worse fuel efficiency with stronger engines and you can only do an event once per day (roughly a minute at zee), so quickly hopping from island to island is kind of pointless.
-The combat is super basic. For ships, stay behind them and shoot them. For monsters, back away and shoot them. That's it.

Overall, I'd give it a 6/10. I loved exploring the world, but once it was explored I had to mine for more stories, killing tons of time in the process. Initial impressions are excellent, but the late game suffers from slow gameplay and the same stories you've heard before. Get this game on sale if you can, since it's worth about 10 hours of great storytelling.

reviewText:
Sunless Sea is such an interesting concept but is hampered by some really poor decisions. There's a reason I call it Funless Sea.

The good part is that the developers have crafted a weird, wonderful world populated with interesting stories and artwork. The mood is great. The world is interesting. The stories are kind of cool and occasionally not just a little messed up in the head. The world is the same close to your base but in every game it gets more and more randomized the further you get. That's a wonderful gameplay idea and I give serious props to the devs for creating such a great universe.

Unfortunately, they didn't know what to do with it. People will talk about the decent writing, the dark mood, the truly unique world that was created when they praise this game. What they don't talk about is the gameplay and that's where this falls flat. There is no direction and there are really no aims in this game. You get in a ship and go...wherever. It doesn't really seem to matter. You'll find a rare workable trade route and do nothing but grind it as long as you can because money is hard to come by. You'll visit the same ports over and over getting nothing but port reports for a few echos (dollars) at a time when it takes tens of thousands to get a new ship. The pace of the ship is ponderous (and that's being kind). So underneath this interesting world the game devolves into a slow, dull grind. It's really a shame because even mediocre gameplay mechanics could have gone a long way here.

Yes, the pace is supposed to reflect the tension of your slowly deteriorating crew. To some respect it does that. But more often than not my head just wants to hit the keyboard from playing this. My time is more valauble than that. Most of the people I've talked to that have enjoyed" the game used cheats to boost their gold to get somewhere in this bore-fest. I love good exploration games
date: but this feels aimless and pointless to me.\n\nNot that I haven't give it a chance. I tried buying it and then returned it under the Steam policy. I tried again when they had a free weekend and really tried to like this game. But I just can't find the fun in it. Funless Sea - such a great world marred by such boring gameplay."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The chilling sound of distant bells rolls over my ragged crew. Their tired faces glance warily into the darkness, apprehending the form of some hideous beast to appear and wreck our vessel. We have been sailing for close to three weeks now, and the mens morale is fading as is our supplies and fuel. I fear we may never reach the shore, and instead be swallowed by the 'Zee, just as it has swallowed our hope and happiness.....

I would heartily recommend Sunless Sea.

PROS

+ Great Atmosphere
+ Great Writing
+ Sailing mechanics
+ Developers are on top of things and respond to comments

CONS

- More trading features
- A little more to do...just more activities and such
- More ships on the Unterzee ( Developer has stated that neutral vessels are coming)

reviewText: This is not a fast game.\n\nIf that does not turn you away, you will devour this game.  Intriguing and thought-provoking worldbuilding, and the very best narrative, quantity considered, i've ever seen in a game.  Sometimes it is hilarious, often it is charming, and usually it is laden with sinister purpose that perpetually leaves you a shade below terrified.  The gameplay is the delectable, perfect mix of challenging but fair.  It's worth your twenty bucks if you have some time to kill.  It's a no-brainer if it's on sale.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game's pretty rad.  It's a very cthuluesque 'Victorian-era London fell out of the crust of the earth when hell-demons invaded and set up beauracracy over the surface and now the survives eke out a living in the murky 'neath' of not-hell,' type setting, expanding on the pretty rad browser-game free RPG 'Fallen London' (formerly Echo Bazaar).

Game's pretty decent.  It's an exploration roguelike, charting the 'zee (sea) trying to keep your crew, health, fuel, supplies, and sanity in check while dodging (or farming) unterzee monsters and pirates.  Half the game you'll actually spend rolling dice checks against your stats to extract vital goodies from various events dripping in lore, and the writing's so great and every failure can yield fresh new insight into this rich setting that I don't even get mad on dying.

Hardly buggy at all, you can hardly tell it's early access but for certain missing features and stories.  This one's worth watching.

reviewText:
Overall  Recommended to fans of indie games, roguelikes, and even fans of flash games. It really does remind me of flash games where you will improve over time, and calmly go through your tasks in the face of danger. However, it really does have more depth than any flash game.

The idea of the game is to become an explorer and meet everyone one could meet. One might have different identifiers (essentially boolean characterstics), companions, etc. Money is only a means to this. In my opinion, discovering everything and progressing the story is primary, but I need money to do it, so sometimes I am coerced into going back to Whither for some extra cash for recon.
The game relies on fuel and food. Neither are too scarce if you scout for the royal navy a lot. Be careful though.
Watch like 5 minutes of gameplay, it's pretty straightforward.

Very atmospheric, the setting is immersive More like submersive, amirite? with a Dickensian England style, even altering English to accomodate the setting. (Even if it's just replacing Sea" with "Zee"

reviewText:
First impressions review: this game is like FTL -- if in FTL you had to watch 10 minutes of space travel every time you madea hyperspace jump to your next station.

A few hours in and I'm already on my third playthrough of the exact same first 45 minutes. I'm afraid to go on, because it's dragging already and the many negative reviews on steam are confirming my concerns with the pace of the game.

Maybe I'll pick it up again sometime, change my opinion, and this review. But for now...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welcome delicious friend, allow me to read some excerpts from my captain's log : I've  killed giant crabs and ate their flesh. An enormous crab ate one of my crew and proceeded to destroy my ship.  An enormous Albino Moray devoured three of my crew in battle before finally dying. I've made literal deals with a devil. I've battled a horde of guinea pigs. I've explored the darkest caverns of the Unterzee and survived (though I can't say the same for my crew). I've smuggled souls from here to Hell and back. I've battled hideous abominations off Port Cecil.  One of my men stole a lifeboat and rowed off into the darkness because I shot a white bat. I murdered a harbinger of Salt (an Unterzee god) and subsequently was cursed. My lover subsequently died because I was cursed. I survived a mutiny. I fought Clayman pirates and died a horrible death. I've scuttled pirate ships and sold them for scrap.  I sold mushroom wine to Pirate-monks. I fought Lifebergs and killed some, while others I appeased with a sacrifice. I explored the frozen wastes of the northern Unterzee. I took a burned girl in as one of my officers. I got murdered by a giant black cloud of death.
I've amassed a fortune smuggling and selling mushroom wine. I've also subsequently ♥♥♥♥♥♥ it all away on shore leave.


The lore surrounding the Fallen London universe is very rich and Sunless Sea definitely captures the atmosphere of it.  If any of this sounds like gibberish you should definitely go check out Fallen London (it's a free browser based game) to get some backstory.

TLDR: I highly recommend this game for fans of Fallen London or people looking for a unique setting filled with all kinds of interesting things. Mediocre combat, great atmosphere, interesting occurences, and fun for short play sessions imo.

TIPS: -The terror meter goes up quite quickly at times and can make journeys tedious as you'll have to stop at a port to reduce terror levels.
-Shore leave is not cheap, so save every echo you get.
-Try trading with the monks on Godfall or smuggling Clay men from Polythreme for some quick cash.
-Buy a decent cannon as early as possible, preferably one with harpoons, since they work best for sea monsters.
If you're fighting Lifebergs make sure you kill them as quickly as possible. They can one shot your starting boat. Or you could just run, but I'll totally judge you for it, plus you don't get their loot :(

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now, this is the first time i post a review of a game, so please don't be too hard on me, when you disagree with something I write. Still, i hope that you will find my review helpful in deciding about buying this game.

Sunless Sea is a game about exploring a world set in darkness, hence there is something creepy about it, though I would not go so far as to call it a horror game. While you explore, you may encounter dangers like giant crabs, corsairs or your own mind, as well as the trouble of running out of supplies/fuel.
It is really merciless, unless you play in merciful mode (but who would do that) where you can save manually. The gameplay itself is rather simple, as you mostly drive your boat around on the hunt for new areas and stories, which leads me to the main point of the game: The story and the atmosphere, both supported by the excellent soundtrack and art-style. You feel so immersed in the game that you think you really just went crazy and became a cannibal only to realize moments later that you are sitting in front of your pc, imagining things.
All in all a very enjoyable game, though sometimes a little too unforgiving and hard on newcomers.

PROS:
-creative Story
-excellent Soundtrack
-fitting art-style
-brilliant atmosphere
-well designed world, there is always something to explore
CONS:
-mediocre gameplay
-predictable AI
-a little too unforgiving
-a little too expensive

reviewText:
I've tried hard to enjoy Sunless Sea, but I cannot recommend it.

THE PROBLEMS
If you're considering buying the game please read the forum postings by people who paid their money and (like me) have been continually frustrated with the game.

To summarize: It's very slow going and grindy. You will die early and often, and be forced to repeat the early game again and again. Neither combat nor trading are open to the early game. Allegedly there's a lot of narrative depth that shows up in the mid-to-late game, but as far as I can tell, they've done a great job hiding it.

Even the developer agrees that these are the core problems in the game:

Originally posted by Developer:Sunless Sea has the punishing early difficulty, permadeath, and some of the randomness of a roguelike. It has the rich story, predictable early-game, slow pace, and flat late-game difficulty arc of a CRPG. We even have a default roguelike permadeath save system and an optional more CRPG-like save system.

This is the source of very nearly everything that’s wrong with the game. It’s left us with an uneven difficulty curve.
Here's a link to the postmortem discussion with the developer at Gamasutra, worth reading if you're on the fence:

Gamasutra Postmortem of Sunless Sea[gamasutra.com]

THE COMMUNITY
Originally posted by Cornuthaum:SS early game needs to be made easier and more accessible, or all you'll be left with is an echo chamber of veterans who know all the little tricks and -don't spot the issues with the early game because they know how to get around them-.
Usually with indie games one can count on a vibrant community of players who are eager to help others enjoy the game. This isn't the case with Sunless Sea. Here you've got a small yet vocal group of Kickstarter / Greenlight / Early Access players with chips on their shoulders, who seem rather upset that others may not love the game in which they are so invested.

When new players ask for starting advice these are typical responses:

Originally posted by HVA God Damned Hippopotamus:There is nothing wrong with the game. This is a case of you being bad.
Originally posted by Tresixth:poor kids... use your head. try and fail, try again, try something different. dont stop trying. cause its not this game thats a fail. its you...
Sadly, the community has also influenced the game in negative ways. Again from the developer's postmortem:

Originally posted by Developers:The most vociferous and enthusiastic forum regulars were veterans who rarely saw or cared about the early-game experience… and so the early-game experience stayed rawer and grindier than it should have been.
Guess what? When the developer refers to his own game as grindy"
date: it's pretty darn grindy.\n\nAnd not very fun."

reviewText:
Sunless Sea is a naval action-roguelike with a bit of a british folklore spin. You play a sea captain tasked with an arbitrary goal (selected at start) and a small boat and crew. Through exploration and challenges, you are expected to grow as a character and gain additional crew, cargo, and special items. There is a great deal of lore to be found to help explain the universe your character lives in as well as his or her backstory and ties to local people and culture that grow as you interact with them.

Sunless Sea takes an interesting approach to handling the whole roguelike mechanic by treating just about everything as an item. Rather than gaining levels, you build secrets from fragments of discovered places and successful challenges, and then spend those secrets on boosting your stats. Additionally, it will be necessary for you to manage the terror stat, which slowly increases whenever you are in dark waters or suffering consequences from failed challenges. Hunger also plays a factor and you will need to keep a healthy amount of supplies handy in order to feed your crew. Lastly you must manage fuel consumption through meticulous navigation and careful use of the oil lamps.

Unfortunately, that’s about where all the good points for this game end. Combat is slow paced and typically the belligerent with the greater firepower or hull strength will win, regardless of piloting skill. The majority of your time will be spent doing tedious errands from point A to point B while desperately trying to conserve fuel, supplies, and mitigating terror. It’s definitely as boring as it sounds and despite all the attempts at creating a humorous or entertaining narrative, the story starts getting repetitive the 3rd or 4th time through.

Simply put, Sunless Sea just wasn’t as fun I thought it was going to be. The premise is interesting: Naval battles in a London-esque setting in a sea “under the sea” fraught with terror and danger. The execution, on the other hand, is incredibly dull and left me wondering what else I could spend my time on. From what I’ve read on forums, the game used to be a lot more fun/playable but a good deal of that has diminished in the light of recent patches. Play at your own risk.
