reviewText:
On its face, Sunless Sea has a lot going for it - interesting lore, beautiful graphical style, and a difficulty that is challenging but not unfair.

Things start to come apart within the first half houf of the game as you realize how painful it is to make any progress in the game. 3 primary resources: Terror, Fuel, and Supplies, are being consumed constantly while at sea. Generally, the only way to acquire these goods is with Echoes. How do you get Echoes? Not easily, that's for sure.

You are encouraged to 'explore' through tooltips as that's the most reliable way to get money. Discovering a new area generates a Port Report which you can turn in to your home base. But you can only do this a limited number of times and then what? Port Reports barely cover your expenses, so all you traveling nets you a partly explored map, but no more Echoes than what you started with. It is disheartening to spend 2 hours sailing around, returning home, and finding out you have less money, health, and supplies than when you started with no advancement in your character.

I checked some guides to find out if I was missing out on a game mechanic. Nope. Most getting started guides involve bee-lining to some very specific places, followed by trading goods between ports for paltry sums. The most absurd strategy involves killing off your captain immediately to pass on your starting gold to your next captain. This is not good game design.

If I was at least rewarded with interesting stories or encounters it might not be so bad, but Sunless is a 100% text based game. It aims for a Lovecraftian flair but comes off pretentious and plodding as you wade through paragraphs of text.

I wanted a game where exploring was rewarded. While it is constantly encouraged through tooltips, you are generally punishd for it. You'll have better luck exploring the Sunless Forums for quick-start guides, but that's not what I signed up for.

reviewText: Easily one of my favorite indie-RPG releases of the past year, Sunless Sea offers addictive challenges and sublime writing that will remind you of the old story-driven RPGs of yesteryear.  The Lovecraftian themes and dark gritty overtones of the Zeefaring life which has no clear cut good/evil paths are definitely some of my favorite aspects of the game.  Though frustratingly difficult at first, Sunless Sea will soon have you questioning your own motives and will make you realize there are no black and white choices, there are only decisions you must make to survive.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI really want to enjoy Sunless Sea as the entire concept of the Fallen London universe really appeals to me. However I find it has the same problem as Dark Souls 1 in that I will usually get irritated by the steep learning curve it provides. For example my ship gets destroyed because I forgot to repair it the last time I was docked. This irritation usuall leads to me blatantly ignoring the game for weeks on end. Despite this I really enjoy the game. I like all the mechanics it employs, the music is some of the best I've ever heard and the stories it provides are intresting and amusing in equal measure.

reviewText:
This game has immense potential. Released just this February, I came into the game expecting some gaps, since that tends to happen with games as of late. Room for upgrades, right? Instead, what I found was a complete and complicated series of storylines that had me riveted as well as frustrated when I couldn't keep my captains long enough to see them through. The difficulty, instead of making it unpleasant, manages to cull an element of replayability.
For example, instead of trying over and over again the same way, you strategize a completely new way to go about the game, from hard zee-beast hunting to trade within the area close to Fallen London. There are storylines that are lengthy and fun to complete, as well as tons of areas to explore that change with each generation of inheritance. Whether it be your progeny taking to the sea or someone who raided your ship, your legacy lives and you explore a new and changed world.
It's an interesting universe, a mix of steampunk and something caught between H. P. Lovecraft and Jules Verne. The method of play is up to you, and there's so many places to take your captain. Even your crew develop their storylines over time. It leaves you multitasking between surviving in an underground ocean and pursuing fascinating stories and exploring an even more fascinating world.

On top of that, the ability to download in more quests and stories, more places to see gives it further elements of replayability that really makes the game appealing. It's beautiful, it's simple, it's intriguing. Phenomenal storylines and atmospheric music. And I highly recommend giving it a shot.

reviewText:
In Fallen London plauged with bats
A rotten carcass devoured by rats
Where slime and malodorous ooze both ran
Through sewers and canals built not by man
Down to a Sunless Sea

So twice five nautical miles around
Where the Funging Station was finally found
A report for the Admiral I came to collect
Yet in the Mushroom forests - only regret
Terror increased by 5, no supplies for me

This is a damn good game and one you should try.

reviewText:
I sailed to the four corners of the zee and back, witnessing every type of horror imaginable. I had tea with a rather pleasant deviless, caroused on an island where the cups scream, and assisted a race of noble guinea pigs in their civil war with egalitarian rats. I fought pirates, sharks, giant crabs. I went to a republic that abides by no laws, including the laws of nature. I aided an archaeologist who sold her soul to a monkey in exchange for digging equipment. I removed many of the internal organs of one of my crewmates, which he thanked me for. And after all that, I got killed by bats. Not demon bats, not giant bats. Just bats.

10/10 would die ignobly again (and I'm sure I will).

P.S. at no point did I embellish the experiences of the game or present things in a disingenuous light. All those things happened to me in one playthrough. And full disclosure, I have not yet seen any demon bats or giant bats, so they may not exist. Or maybe I just haven't run into them yet. Their existence would not at all surprise me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like eldritch horrors? Do you think eldritch horrors are overated and should take a backseat as the old veteran Victorian Gothic shows how it's done? Do you think that simultaneously is a bit too genre and need some classics of English poetry to up the brow? Do you think the English independent video game industry needs an answer to Kentucky Route Zero? Can a finely crafted sentence set you on a pleasing path for hours? Do you think fondly on the Jeeves and Wooster TV show from the 90s with Hugh Laurie and Stephen Fry? Do you like Coleridge?

Yes? Then you'll likely like this game.

reviewText:
one of the best games i have played in a while, beautifully crafted, and more content than you would need for a life time. Whether your sailing the open zea, or wondering if you should burn some supply for fuel to continue sailing on the said zea, it continues to be fun and interesting. it is not only the game that has been written masterfully down to every word but also holds up in the gameplay department. being a previous player of the classic browser king fallen London i fell in love with the universe even more to the point of me just thinking in normal everyday life what i was going to do next which lead to some awkward situations. though the combat at first seems boring as you continue to play the game it fleshes out into some cool ways such as using torpedoes with nets to capture crabs (and other zea critters) live for more meat for your starving crewmen.
overall i think this is a brilliant game that could be a best selling novel if it wanted to but, instead it decided to avoid such linear entertainment and get the best of both worlds a great story along with a brilliant gameplay component. bravo failbetter, bravo.






ps: the devs are not cannibals at least most of them....

reviewText:
If I could give this game a thumbs sideways then that's what it would get.
It's a decent roguelike with a lot of depth to it and an immense amount of lore to explore.
The difficulty level is set at just the right level to give you the one more turn" effect.

However
hoursPlayed: and interesting quests are hidden behind a slow grind for cash. It's not the same kind of grind you would get in a dungeon delving roguelike where you gradually get stronger so that you can delve deeper. It's the kind of grind where you have to do the same trade routes repeatedly with no variation just so you can save up for a slightly bigger/faster/better ship to do it all again.\n\nRepetition is the heart of a roguelike
voteText: learning the systems and going at them again and again
helpfulPercent: but a good one will pepper each life with something interesting and new; and this is where Sunless Sea fails to hit the spot. There's just not enough there at the start to justify getting to the end.\n\nIt's worth buying at a sub $10 price
votesHelpful: but it won't be a game that endears itself for years to come. Buy it or don't."

reviewText:
A spectacular game of daring sea captains who you control one after another, getting swallowed up by the sea. One gets killed by Pirates while another gets killed by a giant shark. Another gets killed by cannibals while the next one dies from an engine blast. Then the next one commits suicide. While the next sacrifices his whole crew to a sea god to heal himself to just get eaten up by a giant sea-crab.

My first ever captain was a philosopher wanting to write a book about the sea under the earth. Gets trapped next to an island from using all the fuel they could find on the steamer and then end up eating all their food. Suddenly a ship appears and we go full cannons on it to be fired back on and sunk in an instant not knowing it was a bunch of pirates and their ship was bigger and better....

Next captain was a veteran from the old war and made a crew of sturdy men and woman. Not to mention the first mate of the last ship made it back to London and signed back on. Off we went and were doing a good job when all of a sudden fuel was running low. Using all the supplies we had we ended up getting stranded right outside the port of London. No one helped us. We were hungry. And the captain pleaded for anyone to help us even the seas gods themselves who he didn't believe in. All of a sudden the ship vanishes and appears far off to nowhere at a castle of a tentacle god. Tentacles reaching out of the castle the crew goes nuts crazy and the captain starts pushing off his own crew into the sea trying to sacrifice them to the creature. Maybe it will give them fuel or food. Anything to get away. The captain starts stabbing himself and killing his fellow crew to the last man but the tentacle giant barely did anything. Just watched as they killed themselves off one by one and the captain dies of his own wounds. Everyone is now dead. No one hears from them again.

The next captain does an amazing job even though he used to be a poet. He gets a house, a wife, a child. Lots of money! Lots of good working crew! Lots of rat people who become his best friends and help work on the ship! Everythings going great! Hes honest and does his contracts, his deliveries, and helps people when he can! And this is the captain I am at right now and hes been alive for over one year in game and most of his crew intact.

The best part? I'm on the hardest difficulty. No saving. No reloading. Every choice you make is final. Which what the game should be! But thats just me! It makes you stand on edge and everything you do has the biggest impact you can think of. Not to mention the game is freaky as hell and actually is scary. The monsters in this game..... Are huge and this game is about surviving the sea not a shootem up RPG. You will get screwed up and your people will die. Your ship will get sunk and you have to live with it because you shouldn't of called that giant creature with bait that you threw over board. It was all your fault sir. All your fault! Oh and timmy jumped overboard and got eaten by that thing. He said he was home? I think he went crazy captain...

Everything you do impacts what happens even with your next captain. They have to live with what the last captain did. Everything you do changes the sea, the people, everything. Its up to you what happens and what you do with your crew.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I recommend the game because it has a very interesting and unique feel to the game.  Really anyone, who likes the idea of being a captain of a ship in the middle of an unexplored, dark, and foggy sea  would be cool, should play this game.

That said, it's not a game that can keep one excited for very long.  First off, the game world is designed to be dreary - but there is only so much dreariness someone can take before they have to go one to something else.  More importantly though, as others have pointed out, after the first few hours of exploring and learning what your limits are - the game becomes a dreary grindfest.

What could be changed about the game to make it more engaging?  It's been a while since I played - but my memory tells me that it was having to repeatedly go to the same places over and over again, simply to collect fuel and supplies or money to buy them, that really made the game feel like it dragged on.  If things changed every time you arrived at a location, that would make it much more interesting to go back there.

reviewText:
This game was a huge surprise. It is incredibly well written and the setting is very well thought, the immersion is total.
Lots of quality all over the place, this game is a work of love.
Potential drawbacks I can think of are: you've got to read all, not only because it should be a pleasure, but also because the game pretty much is a text adventure at its heart. So if you buy this game mainly for the exploration/survival/combat aspects, you'll be disappointed. It does have these elements, and they are also somewhat fleshed out.
But where the game really shines is the writing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ah, sunless sea. How many hours have I wasted wandering from shore to shore, hauling rocks for a living?

This is a newer review, hence I would like to note early that the timed based system is now replaced with a real time attack system where most of it is sitting staring at the enemy and waiting for your cannons to equip. I would personally have prefered to have my cannons loaded and ready for fire, but such is the world of Sunless Sea. The game is very close to a horror game of a lonely little captain and the crew adriff in a vast and unforgiving ocean surrounded by monsters and being driven insane by the fact that even the very crewmate that mans the ships could simply be waiting for the right moment to rip off your face and assume your position as captain as the thing that now lives inside of your skin slowly chew away at your trusted officiers.

I recomended this game out of personal enjoyment, but I feel it also necessary to warn you about the game. The nitpicks I have with the game is simple: the game has nearly no link between narrative and gameplay.

What I mean by this is simple: you start off the game with what might as well be a bamboo raft for all the monsters and enemy ships in the game care. The world of Sunless Sea is beautifully rich in narrative, but following any threads of narratives is nearly impossible between trying not to be sunk by a brigade of crabs and trying to keep track of which islands have to be visited next, to the point where I arrive at islands at the end of the world having completely forgotten not only the story, but also what I wanted to do to get there in the first place.

The world is expansive, the atmosphere is lovely, and the music can swing anywhere from the energetic sounds of cutlass clashing atop a ship's deck to the ballard with a lovely countess in a ballgown to the raspy and bonechilling sounds that seem to rake over your very bones. All of this is lost, however, because the narrative does not reward you nearly as much as menial tasks. I made more from a single trip of hauling stones than three journeys right across the edge of the world and all I did was run across a few pirates which were barely a challenge. Trying to pursue narrative in this game is like showing up to an attack dog show with strips of bacon tied to your scrotum to get 500 bucks of betting money from your best pal. Bold, yes, and even exciting, but it will quickly turn humiliating, unbearably painful, and at the end of it all you will only be missing something important. After the second week sitting in the hospital bed you'll start to wonder whether or not the 500 bucks and the hospital bill that your insurance company refuses to pay out was worth it all when you could make about the same amount after about a week of hard work without all of the peeing out of a tube for the rest of your miserable life" business. And that is the same thing I felt after about my 5th death and retry. Oh
